Tears, drama and controversy. The 2010 Tour de France review

Jake Farrell looks back on the 2010 Tour de France. It brought us drama and controversy and, as the weary cyclists rest for another year, Jake reflects on arguably the greatest race in the world. (Thumbnail credit Alberto Contador, seen here celebrating last year's victory, has now three of the last four Tours. Photo: Lynt via Flickr Creative Commons )

The injustice of Schleck's broken chain could fire him to the Maillot Jaune

Jake Farrell dissects the goings-on in Monday's stage of the Tour De France and questions whether the incident could spur Andy Schleck on. (Thumbnail credit Andy Schleck, the man from Luxembourg, will seek to fight back from Monday's chain-gate. Photo: puliarf via Flickr Creative Commons)

Humdrum final round spoils 150th Open Championship

Louis Oosthuizen might have been a worthy champion at St. Andrews last weekend, but a dull final round wasn't what the Open Championship deserved in its 150th year, writes Sam Morgan (Thumbnail credit Louis Oosthuizen holds aloft the famous Claret Jug. Marie Guilpin via Flickr Creative Commons)

The Tour De France is getting serious as it enters the mountains

Jake Farrell discusses this year's Tour De France as the competition moves up the mountains and assesses the chances of those competing for the Maillot Jaune. (Thumbnail credit Cadel Evans, the current race leader after today's eighth stage. Photo: will_cyclist via Flickr Creative Commons)

Derwent ease to Plate Final victory

By James Bithell

Derwent enacted a small measure of revenge over Alcuin for Tuesday's Cup Final defeat, winning 3-0 in the Plate showpiece on Thursday (Thumbnail credit Ed Lacaille celebrates opening the scoring on five minutes. Photograph by Arran Bowen-la Grange)

Alcuin win College Cup

Alcuin have won the 2010 College Cup, beating Derwent 2-0 in the final. (Thumbnail credit Photo: Peter Iveson)

Beginner's success at University Polo Nationals

By James Bithell

After weeks of blood, sweat and tears, York University Polo Club were finally ready to face their foes at the annual University Polo Nationals (Thumbnail credit Charles Osborne, left, on the charge for York. Photographs courtesy UYPC)

The York Sport Awards 2010

After a year of toil and triumph it was time for the sportsmen and sportswomen of York to sit back and revel in an evening dedicated to their achievements (Thumbnail credit Marlies Neuner, Sportswoman of the Year, and Emily Scott. Photograph by George Lowther)

Walwyn header puts Derwent into College Cup final

Derwent will meet Alcuin in the final of the College Cup, after beating Vanbrugh 1-0 today. (Thumbnail credit Photo: Peter Iveson)

Late Alcuin raid earns Plate Final place

By James Bithell

Goodricke seconds were heading to the Plate Final until a dramatic late intervention from Alcuin's Rhys Spong on Thursday afternoon (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Justyn Hardcastle)

Semi-final preview: Vanbrugh v Derwent

Friday's match brings together free-scoring Vanbrugh and workmanlike Derwent

Five-star Alcuin breeze into the College Cup Final

With five goals from five different scorers, Alcuin cruised into the College Cup final on Wednesday afternoon, beating Halifax with plenty to spare (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Maggie Aslet)

Derwent seconds reach Plate final on penalties

Halifax seconds bossed Tuesday's Plate semi-final but it was Derwent who will line up in the final after prevailing 5-3 on penalties (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Justyn Hardcastle)

Henley Royal Regatta beckons for fast improving UYBC men

After just two months of training, the University of York Boat Club achieved the unprecedented achievement of qualification for the Henley Royal Regatta

College Football titans prepare to battle it out in Cup semi-finals

Halifax will take on Alcuin and Vanbrugh will face Derwent in the semi-finals of the College Cup this week (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Maggie Aslet)

Women rowers among top six at Henley Regatta

The women's squad of the University of York Boat Club travelled down to Henley-on-Thames this weekend for the international event that is the highlight of their rowing calendar: Henley Women's Regatta. (Thumbnail credit Photo: Catherine Oliver)

The Mixer

The Mixer can exclusively reveal a new team will be entering the College Cup next year

The Nouse Sports Awards 2010

Another exceptional year for York's sports teams is nearing its end. Nouse recognises those that have performed oustandingly throughout the course of the season. Words by Leigh Clarke. (Thumbnail credit Photo: Peter Iveson)

Bringing you the World Cup: Interview with Mark Bright and Jonathan Stevenson

As World Cup fever sweeps England, Leigh Clarke talks to BBC commentator Mark Bright and reporter Jonathan Stevenson about covering the biggest football competition on the planet. (Thumbnail credit Mark Bright, co-commentator at the World Cup for the BBC)

Tied Sports Day sets up tight College Sport race

Derwent, Alcuin and Wentworth all collected 14 points towards their overall College Sport tallies at the annual Sports Day on Wednesday (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Maggie Aslet)

Halifax and Goodricke complete Plate line-up

Halifax and Goodricke seconds reached the Plate quarter-finals with convincing wins at the back end of last week (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Justyn Hardcastle)

Alcuin beat Langwith to complete the last four line-up

A late goal from Christy Cormac carried Alcuin through to the semi-finals of the College Cup at the expense of Langwith (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Justyn Hardcastle)

Vanbrugh make no mistake as Alcuin gain Plate victory

Vanbrugh joined Halifax in the Cup semi-finals, beating Wentworth 3-1, while in the Plate, Alcuin seconds overcame Langwith seconds 2-1 (Thumbnail credit Dan Hewitt and Vest Waterson celebrate Vanbrugh's passage to the semis. Photograph by Maggie Aslet)

Barnett at the double as Derwent eliminate James

Derwent produced their best performance of the College Cup to date, beating James 3-1 courtesy of goals from Chris Barnett (2) and Matt Hallam (Thumbnail credit A contentious moment early in the game as James goalkeeper Dom McMahon went unpunished for apparently handling outside the box. Photograph by Maggie Aslet)

Halifax edge into semis with penalty win over Goodricke

Mark Lund was the hero today as Halifax firsts beat Goodricke on penalties to move into the semi-finals of the College Cup (Thumbnail credit Conor Brennan saw his spot-kick saved by Ed Foster. Photograph by Arran Bowen-la Grange)

Derwent progress to Plate semi-finals on penalties

Derwent seconds beat their James counterparts 4-3 on penalties to progress into the last four of the College Cup Plate, following the tournament's first goalless draw (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Maggie Aslet)

Novice men claim victory as Boat Club warm up for Henley

By James Bithell

It's been a busy couple of weeks for the Boat Club as they make final preprations for the Henley Royal Regatta this weekend, with events at Peterborough, Eton and Durham (Thumbnail credit The men's novice four in action at Peterborough. Photograph by Becca Kay)

James and Langwith swap places as Group D ends

James firsts gained the expected victory over Derwent thirds on Friday, but will have to cope without Mark Mcloed in the quarter-finals, while Langwith surrendered top spot after a 1-0 defeat to Halifax seconds (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Peter Iveson)

Alcuin and Derwent secure their quarter-final passage

Alcuin hit Vanbrugh thirds for six on the final matchday in College Cup Group C, while Derwent comfortably beat Wentworth seconds 2-0 (Thumbnail credit Photograph by George Lowther)

York to host Gambian Olympic squad at 2012 games

The University of York will be among a number of venues chosen to host the Gambian Olympic and Paralympic squads during the 2012 London games (Thumbnail credit Photograph by Peter Iveson)
